title: The use of mirror types in typography
content:
Regarding typography and the use of uncommon letter images, I personally do like the (moderate) use of type reflection. Sometimes evidently but also ’undercover’, as they can function as regular types.

Like a mirrored ’z’ (=s) or a mirrored ’w’ (=m). Well, there are several options.

Is this a well-mannered way of creating a nice text image or just a cheap trick from an Illustrator-freak?

 [‹ A nice free font at Fontshop: Baskerville Old Face](http://web.archive.org/web/20080422235854/http:/typophile.com/node/19929 "Go to previous forum topic") [ambigrams in motion ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080422235854/http:/typophile.com/node/19917 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Ringo

comments.content:
That’s a very polite way of telling me I’m talking rubbish. :-)

Maybe I should change the question.

I wonder if one could create (=bring together) a set of characters (types) which, by means of rotation and reflection, cover the whole alfabet.

Let’s say: e and a act as two representatives of one type: e and e-rotated. So do, for example, w and m, or u and n.

Is there a minimal set of characters which are prerequisite for the completion of a whole alfabet? And if so, which set?

Does anyone know about similar typographic experiments?

Do a search for ambigrams here. Not your idea full fleshed out but it’s a start…

peace

My computer at work has this face called “wrongfont” by adobe that seems to be along the same lines as what you’re talking about. I know I’ve seen it used before, but i can’t find it anywhere on the web.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080422235854im_/http:/typophile.com/files/wrongfont_5212.gif)

Hmm, the idea is quite like what I had in mind, but read this way it’s just a little type play, not to be taken too seriously. It’s got some interesting elements, however, like the rotated ampersand, which has become more of a p than I would have expected. I also like the rotation of h into y.

Anyway, I’ll do some more research. Also on the ambigram; some of them look really attractive.

Thx!
